column9: an extremely long and digressive monologue or piece of writing.
column10: ...my 90 minute megaramble with my brother James...
column11: The professor's lecture turned into a megaramble about his personal life.
column12: I didn't have a script, so the episode was a bit of a megaramble.

column9: completely filled with something.

column11: The museum is packed full of interesting exhibits.
column12: This book is packed full of useful information.

column9: including many different types of people or things.
column10: English has very diverse vocabulary.
column11: The city has a very diverse population.

column9: help or assistance.
column10: ...you're getting a kind of filter or helping hand...
column11: Could you give me a helping hand with this box?
column12: She's always willing to lend a helping hand.

column9: acts of showing someone how to do something, or how something works.
column10: I'm presenting them to you in context, with my explanations and demonstrations...
column11: The teacher gave a demonstration of the experiment.
column12: There will be cooking demonstrations throughout the day.

column9: exercises that you do again and again to practise pronunciation.

column11: We did some pronunciation drills in class.
column12: Pronunciation drills can help to improve your accent.

column9: to be remembered by you for a long time.
column10: ...the things that you do remember will stick with you forever...
column11: That song will stick with you all day.
column12: His words have stuck with me ever since.

column9: the words that you can remember and use in your own speech or writing.

column11: It's important to have a large active vocabulary.
column12: Reading can help to increase your active vocabulary.

column9: the way that words are pronounced in a continuous stream of speech, with sounds linking together.

column11: Connected speech can be difficult for learners of English to understand.
column12: We'll be practising connected speech in the next lesson.

column9: the way that some words in a sentence are emphasized or stressed.
column10: Test and pronunciation drills 1 (connected speech and sentence stress)
column11: Correct sentence stress is important for clear communication.
column12: She needs to work on her sentence stress.

column9: feeling slightly ill.
column10: I'm a bit under the weather today.
column11: She's been feeling under the weather for a few days.
column12: I'm sorry I can't come, I'm a bit under the weather.

column9: slightly ill.
column10: To be/feel off-colour
column11: I'm feeling a bit off-colour today.
column12: He was looking a bit off-colour, so I sent him home.

column9: very unhappy.
column10: It also means that you're probably feeling a bit miserable too.
column11: I've been so miserable since he left.
column12: What a miserable day!

column9: physical or mental features that are regarded as indicating a condition of disease.
column10: What were your symptoms?
column11: The symptoms of the flu include a fever and a cough.
column12: If your symptoms persist, you should see a doctor.

column9: very small pieces of sand or stone.
column10: A bit of grit went in my eye.
column11: The road was covered in grit.
column12: I got some grit in my shoe.

column9: a very small patch of colour or light.
column10: It was probably a tiny fleck of paint.
column11: There were flecks of gold in the rock.
column12: She has flecks of green in her eyes.

column9: extremely small pieces of matter.
column10: Grit is small particles of rock, sand or salt.
column11: Dust particles were floating in the air.
column12: The air was full of smoke particles.

column9: people walking, especially in an area also used by cars.
column10: ...or pedestrians from slipping on ice.
column11: The road is closed to traffic, but open to pedestrians.
column12: Pedestrians should use the crosswalk.

column9: a very small piece of dust.
column10: A speck of dust
column11: The room was so clean there wasn't a speck of dust anywhere.
column12: I got a speck of dust in my eye.

column9: a word or phrase that indicates a part or quantity of something, used with an uncountable noun.
column10: ...we make it countable using the partitive 'a speck of'...
column11: 'A piece of' is a partitive used with 'advice'.
column12: Partitives like 'a loaf of' or 'a slice of' are used with 'bread'.

column9: a very small piece of stone.
column10: A crumb of stone
column11: The old wall was starting to crumble, leaving crumbs of stone on the floor.
column12: A crumb of stone fell from the ancient statue.

column9: a very small piece of sand.
column10: A grain of sand
column11: The beach was made up of millions of tiny grains of sand.
column12: I got a grain of sand in my eye.

column9: (of a part of the body) to become larger and rounder than usual.
column10: On monday it swelled up a bit...
column11: My ankle swelled up after I twisted it.
column12: The bee sting made my hand swell up.

column9: to injure your ankle by suddenly stretching or turning it too much.
column10: If you sprain an ankle your ankle swells up.
column11: She sprained her ankle playing tennis.
column12: Be careful on the icy pavement, you don't want to sprain your ankle.

column9: either of the two pieces of skin that can close over each eye.
column10: ...the eyelid, the upper eyelid.
column11: She closed her eyelids and went to sleep.
column12: My eyelid is swollen.

column9: the short curved hairs that grow from the edges of the eyelids.
column10: Your eyelash(es)
column11: She has long, dark eyelashes.
column12: I got an eyelash in my eye.

column9: the strip of hair growing on the ridge above a person's eye socket.
column10: Your eyebrow

column12: She has very thick eyebrows.

column9: a single eyebrow created when the two eyebrows meet in the middle.
column10: Some people have one single monobrow...
column11: He is famous for his distinctive monobrow.
column12: She decided to pluck her monobrow.

column9: the dark circular opening in the centre of the iris of the eye, which varies in size to regulate the amount of light reaching the retina.
column10: The pupil
column11: The doctor shone a light into his eye to check his pupils.
column12: Her pupils were dilated.

column9: (of a part of the body) wider or more open than usual.
column10: ...which can be dilated or constricted.
column11: Her pupils were dilated in the dark.
column12: The doctor gave him some drops to dilate his pupils.

column9: (of a part of the body) narrower than usual.
column10: ...which can be dilated or constricted.
column11: His pupils constricted in the bright light.
column12: The drug causes the blood vessels to constrict.

column9: the coloured circular part of the eye that surrounds the pupil.
column10: The iris
column11: She has beautiful blue irises.
column12: The iris controls the size of the pupil.

column9: the outer or inner corner of the eye.
column10: The corner of your eye
column11: I saw him out of the corner of my eye.
column12: She had a tear in the corner of her eye.

column9: to telephone your place of work to say that you are not coming to work because you are ill.
column10: I phoned in sick, I called in sick.
column11: She called in sick this morning.
column12: I had to call in sick because I had a terrible cold.

column9: a day that you take off work because you are ill, or because you say that you are ill.
column10: A sickie
column11: He took a sickie to go to the football match.
column12: She's been taking a lot of sickies recently.

column9: to take a day off work when you are not really ill.
column10: To throw a sickie
column11: He decided to throw a sickie and go to the beach.
column12: I'm tempted to throw a sickie tomorrow.

column9: to take a day off work when you are not really ill.
column10: To pull a sickie
column11: She pulled a sickie so she could go shopping.
column12: He got caught pulling a sickie.

column9: pretending to be ill or to have a particular feeling.
column10: There's also the suggestion that you might be faking it...
column11: I don't think he's really ill, I think he's faking it.
column12: She was faking it when she said she was happy.

column9: days that you take off work to look after your mental health.
column10: Mental health days / duvet days
column11: Some companies offer their employees mental health days.
column12: I took a mental health day because I was feeling stressed.

column9: days that you take off work when you are not ill but you need a rest.
column10: Mental health days / duvet days
column11: I wish my company offered duvet days.
column12: I'm taking a duvet day tomorrow to relax and watch movies.

column9: to not want to do or deal with something.
column10: ...if you can't face Monday morning.
column11: I can't face going to work today.
column12: She couldn't face telling him the bad news.

column9: to make a sound quieter and less clear.

column12: The sound of the music was muffled by the closed door.

column9: in bed, under the blankets.
column10: Stay under the covers or something.
column11: He stayed under the covers all day.
column12: It's cold outside, I'm going to stay under the covers.

column9: dishonest or unreliable.
column10: I had a dodgy curry last night.
column11: I wouldn't buy a car from him, he seems a bit dodgy.

column9: able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities.
column10: It's really versatile.
column11: He is a very versatile actor.
column12: The new software is very versatile.

column9: an area of land where something is being built.

column11: The construction site is very dangerous.
column12: All visitors to the construction site must wear a hard hat.

column9: to end a phone conversation.
column10: They'll want to hang up as soon as possible.
column11: Don't hang up, I haven't finished talking to you.
column12: She hung up in the middle of our conversation.

column9: just in case.

column11: I went to the station on the off-chance that I might see her.
column12: I'll ask him, on the off-chance that he might be able to help.

column9: to answer a phone call.

column11: The phone rang and rang, but nobody picked up.
column12: I tried calling you, but you didn't pick up.

column9: a machine that answers your phone and records messages.

column9: to end a phone conversation suddenly and unexpectedly.

column12: She got angry and hung up on me.

column9: a system for recording and storing telephone messages.

column11: I'll leave a message on your voicemail.

column9: a weak or timid person.

column11: Don't be such a wuss, it's only a spider.
column12: He's a bit of a wuss when it comes to horror films.

column9: to make fun of someone or something in an unkind way.
column10: If you're not taking the piss they'll probably let it go.
column11: Are you taking the piss out of me?
column12: Stop taking the piss, it's not funny.

column9: to stop thinking or worrying about something.
column10: ...they'll probably let it go.
column11: I know he was rude, but you should just let it go.
column12: It's time to let go of the past.

column9: to continue to feel angry or resentful towards someone for something they have done.

column11: She holds a grudge against him for what he said.
column12: He's not one to hold a grudge.

column9: excellent.

column12: The party was ace.

column9: excellent.
column10: Luke: Wicked
column11: That's a wicked new bike.
column12: We had a wicked time at the concert.

column9: extremely frightening but often exciting.
column10: It's quite hair-raising.
column11: It was a hair-raising drive through the mountains.
column12: He told us a hair-raising story about his adventures.

column9: (of hair) to stand up straight because of fear or excitement.
column10: ...that would make your hair stand up on end.
column11: The ghost story made my hair stand on end.
column12: It was so cold my hair was standing on end.

column9: to speak your thoughts aloud.
column10: The emphasis was to get you talking out loud.
column11: I often talk out loud to myself when I'm working.
column12: It's a good idea to read your essay out loud to check for mistakes.

column9: to laugh in a way that can be heard.

column11: The joke was so funny I laughed out loud.
column12: I literally laughed out loud when I saw his new haircut.

column9: to say your thoughts as they come into your head.

column11: 'What am I doing?' she thought out loud.
column12: Sorry, I'm just thinking out loud.

column9: expressing ideas or feelings in words.
column10: ...actually verbalising the thoughts in your head.
column11: He has difficulty verbalising his feelings.
column12: The course helps students to practise verbalising their ideas.

column9: to be able to think and react to things very quickly without any preparation.
column10: ...and you have to think on your feet.
column11: She's a great presenter, she's very good at thinking on her feet.
column12: In this job, you need to be able to think on your feet.

column9: creating or performing something spontaneously or without preparation.
column10: So it's like improvising, coming up with things off the top of your head.
column11: The actor forgot his lines and had to improvise.
column12: She is very good at improvising.

column2: off the top of your head
column9: from memory, without careful thought.
column10: ...coming up with things off the top of your head.
column11: I can't tell you the answer off the top of my head.
column12: Off the top of my head, I'd say there were about 50 people there.

column9: the rate of a person's progress in gaining experience or new skills.
column10: It's a big learning curve.
column11: The new job has a steep learning curve.
column12: I'm still on the learning curve.

column9: a situation in which someone has to learn a lot in a short period of time.
column10: ...so there's a steep learning curve at the start...
column11: The new software has a steep learning curve.
column12: It was a steep learning curve for me when I started my own business.

column9: reaches a level or period where there is no change or development.
column10: ...but then the challenge plateaus later on.
column11: Sales have plateaued in recent months.
column12: My progress with the language has plateaued.

column9: in a way that is famous for something bad.
column10: This software has a notoriously steep learning curve.
column11: The exam is notoriously difficult.
column12: He is notoriously bad at remembering names.

column9: to try to do something.
column10: I thought I'd give it a go.
column11: I'm not sure if I can do it, but I'll give it a go.
column12: Why don't you give it a go?

column9: to try to do something.
column10: To have a go (at something)
column11: I'll have a go at fixing it.
column12: Would you like to have a go?

column9: to try to do something.
column10: To give something a try
column11: I'm not sure if I'll like it, but I'll give it a try.
column12: She decided to give it a try.

column9: to try a new activity to see if you are good at it.
column10: To try your hand at something
column11: I've always wanted to try my hand at painting.
column12: She decided to try her hand at writing a novel.

column9: used to give permission.
column10: No, by all means. Go ahead.
column11: 'Can I have a look?' 'By all means.'
column12: By all means, please help yourself to some more cake.

column9: a typical quality or an important part of something.
column10: ...different features of natural pronunciation...
column11: The car has a lot of new safety features.
column12: The new software has some interesting new features.

column9: a speech sound that is not a vowel.
column10: Two types of consonant: 'stop consonants'...
column11: The word 'cat' has two consonants and one vowel.
column12: He has difficulty pronouncing some consonants.

column9: a speech sound produced by humans when the breath flows out through the mouth without being blocked by the teeth, tongue, or lips.
column10: ...and is followed by a vowel at the beginning of the next word.
column11: The word 'apple' begins with a vowel.
column12: The vowels in English are a, e, i, o, u.

column9: to change from one state or condition to another.
column10: Instead you transition to the next consonant sound.
column11: The company is transitioning to a new computer system.
column12: She is transitioning from being a student to being a professional.

column9: sounds that are added between two words to make them easier to say, such as a /j/ or /w/ sound.
column10: ...you need to add a consonant between them - these are called intrusive sounds.
column11: The intrusive /j/ sound is often used after words ending in a high front vowel.
column12: 'I am' can be pronounced with an intrusive /j/ sound.

column9: shaped like a circle or a curve.
column10: Some vowels at the ends of words leave your lips rounded...
column11: She has a round face and big, blue eyes.
column12: The table has rounded corners.

column9: hints or tips.
column10: ...and to give you a few pointers as to how to replicate fluent speech.
column11: He gave me a few pointers on how to improve my presentation.
column12: Can you give me some pointers on how to use this software?

column9: to make an exact copy of; to reproduce.
column10: ...to give you a few pointers as to how to replicate fluent speech.
column11: The experiment was difficult to replicate.
column12: She has been unable to replicate her early success.

column9: the unstressed central vowel, represented by the symbol /ə/ in the International Phonetic Alphabet.
column10: Often, weak forms of words have a schwa sound in place of the vowel.
column11: The schwa sound is the most common vowel sound in English.
column12: The word 'about' begins with a schwa sound.

column9: the main stress in a sentence or phrase.
column10: Usually the tonic stress in the sentence or phrase...
column11: The tonic stress usually falls on the last important word in a sentence.
column12: Changing the tonic stress can change the meaning of a sentence.

column9: to be a sign of; to indicate.
column10: This going up or going down tends to denote different things.
column11: A red light is used to denote danger.
column12: The symbol denotes a change in the music.

column9: explanations or opinions of what something means.
column10: These are my interpretations and how I'm choosing to say them...
column11: The poem is open to several interpretations.
column12: What's your interpretation of the events?

column9: not supporting any side in a disagreement, competition, or war.
column10: ...in hopefully a neutral way.
column11: He has a very neutral accent.
column12: I'm trying to remain neutral in this argument.

column9: very small pieces of sand or stone.
column10: A bit of grit went in my eye.
column11: The road was covered in grit.
column12: I got some grit in my shoe.

column9: a very small piece of dust.
column10: Not even a speck of dust anywhere.
column11: The room was so clean there wasn't a speck of dust anywhere.
column12: I got a speck of dust in my eye.

column9: (of a part of the body) became larger and rounder than usual.
